meta.title: Drugs Acting on Ganglia & Anti Smoking Drugs

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy started smoking his first cigarette. Which Of the following effects was most likely elicited by nicotine soon after smoking?

options.label: B
options.text: Dilation of the skin and splanchnic vessels

options.label: C
options.text: Increased epinephrine secretion from the adrenal Medulla

questions.correct_answer: C. Increased epinephrine secretion from the adrenal Medulla
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased epinephrine secretion from the adrenal Medulla

Highyeild:

By activating Nicotinic neuronal receptors , nicotine increases the release of epinephrine from chromaffin cells of the adrenal Medulla, which is the only peripheral organ able to synthesize epinephrine.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, B, and D – nicotine causes effects opposite to those given in options.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presented to her physician complaining that he felt fearful, helpless, and worried almost continuously during the day. The history of the patient indicated that he was a difficult child to manage and often impulsive And unproductive in school. he started smoking at the age of 17 and now smoked two packs of cigarettes daily. He tried to quit smoking several times with no success. The Physician suggested trying a drug that was effective in treating both depressive and attention deficit disorders, as well as In smoking cessation. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bupropion Bupropion is an antidepressant that was also found to be effective in treating attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and is approved as an adjunct in the management of smoking cessation. Because the patient has symptoms of both depression and ADHD and wants to quit smoking, bupropion can be an appropriate drug.

Highyeild:

Mechanism of action of nicotine present in smoke : Tobacco →Nicotine →Alpha4Beta2 receptor activation →Release of dopamine →Increase in reward function and relaxation These Alpha4Beta2 receptors undergo desensitization quickly and that leads to an increase in the amount of tobacco in a person turning into an addiction.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options: A and D - are effective in ADHD but are not antidepressants. Option: B – The antidepressant paroxetine is not effective in ADHD.

Extraedge:

Bupropion vs buspirone Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant with anti-smoking properties. Buspirone is an agonist at presynaptic 5-HT1A autoreceptors and is indicated in generalized anxiety disorders.

Table:

BUPROPION USES Depression: Bupropion is widely used in combination with SSRIs Prevention of seasonal depressive disorder Smoking cessation treatment ADHD: 150 mg per day Neuropathic pain: 150 mg BD for 6 weeks

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman smoker expresses a desire to Quit smoking. She has a 10-pack-year history of smoking but no other health issues. She wants to try varenicline, a drug she recently heard about, to help her Quit. Which of the following side effects of varenicline Is she most likely to encounter?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Abnormal dreams Varenicline is thought to decrease nicotine cravings by stimulating neuronal nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs). This provides a moderate level of stimulation in place of nicotine, making quitting easier. It also blocks the full effects of nicotine by competing with the binding sites in cases where a patient on varenicline does smoke. These occur in about 10% of patients.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B - Gastric ulcers have been reported with varenicline but much less commonly than abnormal dreams. Of the side effects listed, abnormal dreams appear to be by far the most common. Option: C - Pancreatitis has been reported with varenicline but much less commonly than abnormal dreams. Pancreatitis is more commonly caused by some nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors such as didanosine. Of the side effects listed, abnormal dreams appear to be by far the most common. Option:D - Photosensitivity has been reported with varenicline but much less commonly than abnormal dreams. Of the side effects listed, abnormal dreams appear to be by far the most common.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who is a 50-pack-year smoker (2.5 packs per day for 25 years) complains of chest Pain just after he smokes a cigarette. What is the most likely explanation for this finding?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nicotine-induced vasoconstriction

Highyeild:

Many patients with peripheral vascular disease experience an exacerbation of symptoms with smoking. For example, nicotine-induced vasoconstriction can decrease coronary blood flow, adversely affecting a patient with angina. Stimulation of the parasympathetic ganglia also increases the motor activity of the bowel. At higher doses, blood pressure falls, and activity ceases in both the gastrointestinal (GI) tract and bladder musculature as a result of a nicotine-induced block of parasympathetic ganglia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A - There is no indication that this patient has suffered a cardiac event. Option: C - Pulmonary embolism can occur because of a hyper-coagulable state, but this is unlikely, given the presence of this patient. Option:D - No data is given to suggest stroke volume change

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a 30-pack-year history of Smoking and known chronic obstructive pulmonary disease complain of intermittent cough. Physical Examination reveals wheezing, which is suggestive of Bronchospasm. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ipratropium aerosol

Highyeild:

Anticholinergics Ipratropium bromide, Tiotropium bromide ACTIONS: Relaxes bronchial smooth muscle may increase mucociliary clearance act in larger airways less effective than sympathomimetics suitable for prophylactic use combination is useful very few side effects - safe Ipratropium Aerosol is the drug of choice, especially in a patient who cannot tolerate an adrenergic agonist, that would dilate the bronchioles. It would work well in this patient with a history of known COPD and Smoking.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B - Mecamylamine is a ganglionic blocker And completely inappropriate in this situation. Option: C - Nicotine would further aggravate his addiction Because this patient is already a known smoker. Option:D - Oxygen would improve aeration but will not relieve bronchospasm

questions.text: A 56-year-old man who has smoked two packs of Cigarettes per day for 50 years has chronic bronchitis. he has tried to quit five times in the past but felt she Could not go long without a cigarette. The nicotine in Her cigarettes stimulates many cells in her body by Binding certain receptors. Which of the following Drugs blocks nicotinic receptors?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hexamethonium

Highyeild:

Hexamethonium is an Nn-type channel antagonist. Nicotinic cholinergic receptors are ligand-gated positive ion channels. They are so named because they are the receptors that the drug nicotine binds. They are found on muscles at the neuromuscular junction (NM type) and in postganglionic neurons in the autonomic ganglia (NN type). When acetylcholine or nicotine binds the receptor, the channel pore opens and positive sodium ions flow through it.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A - Atropine is a muscarinic cholinergic antagonist. It does not antagonize nicotinic cholinergic receptors. Option: B - Bethanechol is a muscarinic cholinergic agonist. It does not antagonize nicotinic cholinergic receptors. Option:D - Metoprolol is a b1adrenergic antagonist. It does not antagonize nicotinic cholinergic receptors.

Extraedge:

Newer non-FDA approved drugs : Cytisine: Plant alkaloid (action similar to varenicline ) Clonidine (it also has anti-smoking properties) These are the emerging drugs that are not FDA-approved yet.

Table:

Ganglionic blockers Nicotine, Hexamethonium, Mecamylamine, Trimethaphan · Ganglionic blockers compete with Ach to bind with nicotine receptors of both Parasympathetic and Sympathetic ganglia · Ganglionic blockers divided into two groups: 1. Drugs such as nicotine, which initially stimulate the ganglia and then block them because of a persistent depolarization 2. Drugs such as hexamethonium, mecamylamine, and trimethaphan, which block ganglia without any prior stimulation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about the normal functioning of the nicotinic receptors in a 19-year-old male college student-athlete from the College baseball team?

options.label: A
options.text: Nicotine at high doses stimulates the receptor

options.label: B
options.text: Nicotinic receptors are located in the adrenal cortex

options.label: C
options.text: Nicotinic receptors are located in the autonomic Ganglia

options.label: D
options.text: Nicotinic receptors located at the neuromuscular Junction are known as NN receptors

questions.correct_answer: C. Nicotinic receptors are located in the autonomic Ganglia
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nicotinic receptors are located in the autonomic Ganglia Nicotinic receptors are located in the autonomic ganglia. Nicotine at low concentrations stimulates the receptor and at high concentration blocks the receptor. Nicotinic receptors are located in the CNS, adrenal medulla, autonomic ganglia, and the neuromuscular junction (NMJ). Those at the NMJ are sometimes designated NM and the others, NN. The nicotinic receptors of autonomic ganglia differ from those of the NMJ. For example, ganglionic receptors are selectively blocked by hexamethonium , whereas NMJ receptors are specifically blocked by tubocurarine.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A - Nicotine at low doses stimulates the receptor and at high doses blocks the receptor. Option: B - Nicotinic receptors are located in the adrenal medulla. Option:D - Nicotinic receptors located at the neuromuscular junction are known as NM receptors.
